awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research:Digital SubCarrier Multiplexing  (DSCM) Networks: from the Core to the Access
awd_abstract_narration:
Internet traffic is experiencing a rapid growth driven by massive video streaming, cloud computing and the Internet of Things. Green networking is more important than ever to keep energy consumption under control while still guaranteeing good service quality. Packet switching is the standard practice in high speed Internet, enabled by routers and switches that perform electronic packet store-and-forward at every intermediate node. In a typical router, up to 60 percent of its energy is used for packet forwarding. Circuit switching, on the other hand, does not require per-packet store-and-forward and can potentially be more energy efficient.  Current practice places optical circuits on a fixed grid of optical frequences. This fixed grid may waste valuable optical spectrum if an optical circuit is carrying less than the maximum capacity.  Thus both the research community and industry are investigating grid-less approaches. In particular, Digital Subcarrier Multiplexing (DSCM)is a circuit-oriented approach with high spectral efficiency and robustness against signal quality corruption and which enables flexible spectrum and grid-less transmission in optical networks. 

This project leverages DSCM to extend the circuit-oriented practice from the optical network core all the way to the network periphery (including metro, access and campus segments) ultimately offering dedicated broadband DSCM circuits to end-users. DSCM traffic bypasses both Ethernet switches and Internet Protocol routers, and eliminates the energy consumption associated with their packet store-and-forward requirements. The project also explores a Hybrid-DSCM-Ethernet network architecture in which DSCM circuits and Ethernet frames coexist in the access/campus networks. The transmission and network cross-layer nature of this research effort promotes partnerships among different institutions and research areas, and provides graduate and undergraduate students the opportunity to do research solving real-world scientific problems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated and implemented the use of circuit switching techniques to offer high quality of service (QoS) to applications that require high-performing network connectivity.  Digital subcarrier multiplexing (DSCM) was explored as a complementary technology to achieve fine-granularity dedicated circuits that can extend all the way to the application endpoints, e.g., a radio head in a cellular network. In addition, A Software Defined Networking (SDN) solution was adopted to jointly orchestrate electronic layers, DSCM layer, and Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) layer.

The work carried out by the UTD team primarily focused on multi-domain SDN solutions in which the resources of the optical layer (WDM and DSCM) and the packet switching L3/L2 layer, along with the connected compute nodes are closely orchestrated to achieve improved networking and computing services.  Coordination of various open-source controllers was achieved and publicly demonstrated through the use of the PROnet Orchestrator module, entirely developed by the UTD team.  The earlier version of the PROnet Orchestrator was completely redesigned and newly implemented using Java, which has facilitated the integration of the Orchestrator with the following open-source controller modules: ODL, Ryu, Transport-PCE, OpenStack, and Kubernetes. Several network equipment manufacturers were invited to contribute their latest products in order to build a series of testbeds with increasing complexity. Stampede nodes from TACC were repurposed to create compute sites (cloud and edge) interconnected through the provided network equipment. A number of demos showcased the work performed.

A first set of demos took place at SuperComputing (2018 and 2019) and OFC (2019, 2020, and 2021) and showcased the feasibility of resource orchestration across multiple domains and multiple vendors. In particular, OpenROADM optical equipment from a total of seven vendors was integrated to form a single open optical network (OON) with client data rates ranging from 10Gbps up to 400Gbps.  The optical resources provided by the OpenROADM equipment were automatically configured by the PROnet Orchestrator to realize advanced services, e.g., facilitating the massive migration of virtual machines from one compute site to another, or the dynamic creation of a federated edge computing system that can quickly accommodate sudden spikes in requested load.

This effort also led to the definition and experimental demonstration of a federated edge computing system in which compute resources at multiple edge sites are dynamically aggregated together to form distributed Super-cloudlets that dynamically respond and optimally adapt to varying application-driven loads. A unique feature of the Super-cloudlet architecture is the dynamic provisioning of circuits between edge sites that are combined to form a Super-cloudlet.  For high data rate and extremely low latency between the edge compute resources WDM circuits are created, i.e., wave services. For lower data rate requirements DSCM circuits may be deployed in place of the wave services.

Another set of demos showcased the possibility of performing live migration of 5G virtual network functions between edge computing sites over dynamically created wave services. More specifically, the  testbed in this set of demos integrated the Software Defined Networking (SDN) features described above and Network Function Virtualization (NFV) capabilities ? which is used to experimentally demonstrate the key functionalities that are required by Virtual Network Function (VNF) fault-tolerant methods. OpenROADM compliant equipment was used to implement the programmable backhaul of a Next Generation Radio Access Network (NG-RAN) Non-standalone (NSA) architecture running 4G Evolved Packet Core (EPC) with the 5G next-generation NodeB (gNB). The implemented radio protocol stacks are from Open Air Interface (OAI), with the addition of new key functionalities that are provided by the UTD team to achieve successful migration of the radio modules over the programmable optical backhaul.

A total of eighteen UTD students participated in this project, of whom seven are women and two are Hispanic. Two of the three students who completed their MS while working on the project activities decided to pursue their PhD at UTD. Of the eleven PhD students who have been contributing to this project, seven have already completed their degree and are all working in high-tech companies in the USA. Six UG students were also involved in the project to broaden their knowledge and understanding of SDN technologies. Most of these students had the opportunity to interact and also directly work with a number of network engineers who are with major companies in the telecom sector, like AT&T, Ciena, Cisco, Fujitsu, ECI (now Ribbon), Infinera, Juniper, Nokia, and Orange. Not surprisingly, some of these students decided to join one of these companies upon their graduation, experiencing flawless transitions from the university research-oriented lab setting into the highly-competitive and product-oriented commercial environment.


Last Modified: 09/14/2021
Modified by: Marco Tacca

Images (1 of )
  • In the PROnet testbed, the SDN orchestrator coordinates OpenStack (Kubernetes, Virtual Network Function (VNF), etc.), Ethernet controllers and optical controllers, e.g., TransportPCE: an openROADM controller for equipment by Ciena, Cisco, Fujitsu, ECI (now Ribbon), Infinera, Juniper, and Nokia.
    Andrea Fumagalli
    Public Domain
    Marco Tacca
    Figure 1
  • Two UTD students are staging the OpenROADM testbed demonstration at OFC?20 in San Diego, CA. The demonstration consisted of 4 ROADM nodes and a number of transponders connected to Ethernet switches, which in turn were connected to a number of repurposed Stampede compute nodes.
    Andrea Fumagalli
    Public Domain
    Marco Tacca
    Figure 2
  • Live migration of virtual Evolved Packet Core (vEPC) components running as VMs and Docker containers without disconnecting user equipment (UE) from the radio service. The vEPC components are migrated over a dedicated optical circuit created by the PROnet Orchestrator.
    Andrea Fumagalli
    Public Domain
    Marco Tacca
    Figure 3
